sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten letter from Harden to Schenker, dated October 13, 1894
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Harden denies that he will try prevent Schenker from publishing his material wherever he chooses; and he commiserates with Schenker over a presumed slight by Hermann Bahr of Die Zeit.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Harden, Maximilian; Schenker, Heinrich; Bahr, Hermann; Die Zeit; Gelber

An [/] Herrn Dr. H. Schenker in Wien Wohnung III Fraungasse 1
nein, so tyrannisch bin ich doch nicht, Sie in der Verwerthung Ihrer Arbeiten irgend zu geniren. Geben Sie ruhig dem kleinen Mamooth, The reference is uncertain. was Sie wollen.

Die „Zeit“ ist eine böse Enttäuschung. So wenig hätte ich doch unserem H. B. Hermann Bahr (1863-1934), a prolific music and theater critic who wrote for many leading magazines, and was an editor of the Viennese magazine Die Zeit, held an extremely progressive aesthetic of continual artistic revolution against existing styles, for which view Harden dubbed him the “Man of The-Day-After-Tomorrow” [“der Mann von Übermorgen”]. nich zugetraut. Aber vielleicht wirds <strike>d</strike> noch besser.
Besten Gruß Ihnen u. Gelber Probably the scholar of German language and literature, Adolph Gelber (1856-1923). Von Ihrem [signed:] Harden

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, undated; postmarked October 13, 1894

tei:translation.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] German Imperial Post Postcard
To Dr. H. Schenker in Vienna Address III Fraungasse 1
No, I am not at all so tyrannical as to hamper you in any way from using your own works. You are free to give the little mammoth whatever you please.
Die Zeit is a terrible disappointment. I wouldn’t have expected so little even from our H. B. But perhaps it will yet turn out better.
